DataElement.preferredName: Smoking Nicotine Metabolite Ratio Nanogram per milliliter
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The act of puffing and/or inhaling smoke from a lit cigarette, cigar, or pipe._A biomarker of nicotine clearance that uses the ratio of two nicotine metabolites derived from smoking (3'-hydroxycotinine [3HC]/cotinine). This ratio reflects the activity CYP2A6 enzyme in the liver, and captures environmental influences on nicotine clearance as well._A biomarker of nicotine clearance that uses the ratio of two nicotine metabolites derived from smoking (3'-hydroxycotinine [3HC]/cotinine). This ratio reflects the activity CYP2A6 enzyme in the liver, and captures environmental influences on nicotine clearance as well._A unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one microgram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one liter. The concept also refers to the unit of mass density (volumetric mass) defined as the density of a substance which mass equal to one microgram occupies the volume of one liter.

This ratio reflects the activity CYP2A6 enzyme in the liver, and captures environmental influences on nicotine clearance as well.

A unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one microgram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one liter. The concept also refers to the unit of mass density (volumetric mass) defined as the density of a substance which mass equal to one microgram occupies the volume of one liter.

ReferenceDocuments.name: PQT
ReferenceDocuments.description: laboratory protocol for measuring cotinine and trans-3'-hydroxycotinine in serum and saliva, which is used by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and for National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey cotinine analyses
